thread.title: Palmetto Sunrise: Biden out, Clinton in committee’s crosshairs
thread.title_full: Palmetto Sunrise: Biden out, Clinton in committee’s crosshairs - Post and Courier

author: Gavin Jackson
title: Palmetto Sunrise: Biden out, Clinton in committee’s crosshairs
text:
Vice President Joe Biden, with his wife Dr. Jill Biden, right, and President Barack Obama announces that he will not run for the presidential nomination, Wednesday, Oct. 21, 2015, in the Rose Garden of the White House in Washington. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin) × COLUMBIA – After months of speculation and soul-searching, Vice President Joe Biden announced Wednesday that he would not run for president.
Flanked by his wife Dr. Jill Biden and President Barack Obama in the Rose Garden, Biden concluded that in light of a continued grieving process for him and his family over the death of his son Beau, the time for him to run for the presidency has passed.
“I will not be a presidential candidate, but I will not be silent,” Biden said during his 14-minute speech .
In what amounted to a stump speech, Biden gave a glimpse of what his candidacy would look like. the 72-year-old Biden would work to maintain Obama’s legacy, improve college affordability and focus on growing the middle class.
Fundraisers for Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton’s campaign have already said Biden’s move is bringing around new donors.
After today she may see even more donors come to her defense.
Clinton, the former Secretary of State, goes before South Carolina Republican Rep. Trey Gowdy’s Select Committee on Benghazi in an open meeting that begins at 10 a.m. ( watch here live )
The committee has suffered several snags, including on Wednesday when Democrats on the committee released the 307-page transcript of former Clinton aide Cheryl Mills, from a closed-door hearing in September.
Republican presidential candidate and former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee will be campaigning at Spill the Beans in Greenville this afternoon before attending a dinner in Gaffney this evening.
Former Maryland Gov. Martin O’Malley will be in the state today for the first time since August. Part of the Democratic presidential candidate’s eighth visit will focus on gun policy reform during an event at Mt. Moriah Baptist Church in North Charleston. From there he’s scheduled to participate in a 3:45 p.m. town hall as part of the College of Charleston’s Bully Pulpit Series.
